name: The Hunted
caption: DC20 Playtest Adventure
description:
This adventure is designed to be setting agnostic and is presented in a way to ease those dropping this introductory story into any world.

Party Level: This adventure is written for 1st-level PCs, though it can be tailored to fit slightly higher-level characters with a few tweaks.

system.description: The Krasis croaks revealing all creatures within 15 Spaces to itself and any creature with Echosight for 1 round.

system.description: When the Krasis is hit by a Ranged Attack within 5 Spaces, it can leap on top of the creature, landing in a Space adjacent to the attacker. The target must make a Physical Save. Failure: The target is knocked Prone.

owycTHWHtGSAwfhf.description: Use Legendary Action Point instead of normal Action Point.

system.description: The Krasis has DisADV on Attacks against creatures not revealed by Echo, unless theyâ€™ve Attacked it since the end of its last turn.
Melee, 2 Spaces, 2 Slashing.

owycTHWHtGSAwfhf.name: Use Legendary AP
owycTHWHtGSAwfhf.description: Use Legendary Action Point instead of normal Action Point.

system.description: Melee, 5 Spaces, 2 Bludgeoning.

owycTHWHtGSAwfhf.name: Use Legendary AP
owycTHWHtGSAwfhf.description: Use Legendary Action Point instead of normal Action Point.

system.description: The Krasis can take a running jump in place of its standing jump

The Krasis can spend any number of Legendary AP to take an Action at the end of any PCâ€™s turn.

System Tip: Default is 4. Change it to match number of your players.

owycTHWHtGSAwfhf.name: Use Legendary AP
owycTHWHtGSAwfhf.description: Use Legendary Action Point instead of normal Action Point.

system.description:
These happen at the start of each round of combat, always going before any creatureâ€™s turn.

Round [x]: Summon The Brood

The Krasis summons a number of additional Young Krasis equal to the current round number [x], but none of them can enter combat closer than 5 Spaces away from a PC.

owycTHWHtGSAwfhf.name: Use Legendary AP
owycTHWHtGSAwfhf.description: Use Legendary Action Point instead of normal Action Point.

system.description:
The Krasis makes a contested Martial Check to consume 1 creature it has Grappled.

While Consumed: Target is Restrained and takes 1 Corrosion damage at the start of its turn.

Escape Consume: When the Krasis loses 5 HP, it must make a DC 15 Physical Save. Failure: The Consumed creature is vomited into an adjacent Space and is no longer Grappled.

owycTHWHtGSAwfhf.name: Use Legendary AP
owycTHWHtGSAwfhf.description: Use Legendary Action Point instead of normal Action Point.

system.description: Spell Attack vs PD, 3 Space Cone, 3 Corrosion.

owycTHWHtGSAwfhf.name: Use Legendary AP
owycTHWHtGSAwfhf.description: Use Legendary Action Point instead of normal Action Point.

system.description: The Young Krasis croaks, revealing all creatures within 5 Spaces to itself and any creature with Echosight for 1 round.
Melee Attack, 1 Slashing damage.
The Young Krasis has DisADV on Attacks against creatures not revealed by Echo, unless theyâ€™ve Attacked it since the end of its last turn.
Ranged Attack 3 Spaces, 1 Corrosion Damage.

Choose a creature that can see or hear you within 5 Spaces. Make an Attack Check, Influence Check or Intimidation Check (your choice) contested by the targetâ€™s Mental Save.

Contest Success: The target is TauntedÂ (DisADV on Attack and Spell Checks against creatures otherÂ than you) by you on their next Attack or Spell Check.

Full Taunt: You can spend an additional 1 AP to have theÂ Taunted Condition last until the end of your next turn.

System Tip: By default this item is configured to use Attack Check. You need to edit "Roll" Tab to change it to Intimidation Check.
During Combat, Buff gains the Bonuses, Resistances, and Penalties of Rage (already included in his stat block).
Buff has ADV on Might Checks and Saves.
Buff can move up to 2 Spaces immediately before making a Melee Attack, without expending movement.
Gruff has ADV on Saves against being Intimidated, Rattled, or Frightened.
Gruff deals +1 damage against creatures that are Grappled.
When a creature enters Gruffâ€™s Melee Range, he can make an Opportunity Attack against it with an Unarmed Strike.
Any creature Attacked by Haze is Exposed against the next Attack made against it before the start of her next turn.
Haze has a Climb Speed equal to his Speed.
All of Nightmareâ€™s Attacks act as MP Effects for the purpose of Spell Duels. Additionally, Nightmare can perform Spell Duels but canâ€™t make Opportunity Attacks.
Nightmare creates an Illusion of herself within 15 Spaces. Nightmare can only maintain 1 illusion at a time.
Spell Attack vs MD, 10 Spaces, 1 Psychic.

Spell Attack vs MD, 5 Space Aura around her Silent Image, 1 Psychic damage to each target.

Targets must make a Repeated Int Save.

Failure: Itâ€™s Rattled by the Silent Image and Nightmare.
Nightmare creates a magical symbol within her space for 1 minute. She has ADV on all Spell Checks while within this space.
Raven has ADV on Saves against being Blinded.
Raven isnâ€™t affected by Difficult Terrain.
Raven has a Climb Speed equal to her Speed.
Raven takes Disengage Action and moves 2 Spaces.
When Raven is hit by an Attack, she can reduce the damage taken by 1.
When Shadow takes Radiant damage he has DisADV on his next Attack.
Shadow has ADV on Saves against being Taunted or moved against his will.
All of Shadowâ€™s Attacks act as MP Effects for the purpose of Spell Duels. Additionally, Shadow can perform Spell Duels, but canâ€™t make Opportunity Attacks.
Spell Attack vs MD, 10 Spaces, 1 Umbral.
Shadow restores 3 HP to a creature he can see within 10 Spaces.
Healing Potions are crafted to magically heal wounds whenÂ drank. These are small (usually red) vials of liquid that areÂ small doses but potent in healing.
2 Poison damage if consumed
You can drink this potion as an Action to become Invisible for 10 minutes, or until you make an Attack Check or Spell Check.

This small Trap can be deployed in your Space as an Action.

Any creature that doesn't know it's there will activate it when they enter that space.

Once activated, the trap creates a 5 Space Aura of complete silence for 1 minute. All creatures within this Aura are Deafened until they leave.

text.content:
DC20 Playtest Adventure DC20 Playtest Adventure

â€œThe Huntedâ€

Adventure Outline

PCs create their own monster hunting quest

Social Skill Challenge (tryouts)+

Character Introductions

Exploration

Travel to get to the site of the ruins

Combat Skill Challenge (capture monster)

Ambush Betrayal by Rivals

Short Rest

Big Monster Attacks

DC Tip: If you need to shorten the Adventure because time is running out, you can always combine the two combats into 1 by having the Big Monster show up DURING the fight against the Rivals. Only do this if your PCs are winning against the Rivals. If the fight is close, then you can have the fight against the Rivals be the â€œfinal boss fightâ€ instead.

Credits

Creator of DC20: Alan Bjorkgren (The Dungeon Coach)

Game Design Director: Eddie Blanton (Purius)

Alpha Rule Review Team: Evan Bosco (Nexus), Schyler Fontenot (Sky), Jason Thuillez, Daniel Martinez, Kaelon Fullmer (Ralaris Maps), Anna Keelin Fitzgerald (Fitz), Marco Pagnini (Pagnabros), StÃ©phane April, Codi Cook

Art Director: Eric â€œbugâ€ Bates

Graphic Designer: Mark MacPherson (Intrepid)

Once youâ€™re ready to begin the adventure, open with the following scene by reading the green text boxes aloud, stopping for other prompts and details between them whenever you see normal text.

Adventure Introduction

We start this journey within the small city of Wildfangâ€¦ The wilds cling strongly to the edges of the city and are littered with aggressive monsters that prowl the extremely diverse wilderness. A desert lies to one side of the city, forests to 2 of the others, and a towering mountain range defines the last. The people that live here wear thin and breathable clothing to protect themselves against the hot weather, and most carry bows or knives fit for hunting and defending themselves.

With visions of adventure and conquests dancing in your minds, you and your companions head to the bounty board of the Bloodsworn. Bounties depicting wild beasts and dangerous foes clutter the weathered post. A brief gust of wind rustles the fliers, detaching one of them and sending it down to the ground at your feet. The tattered paper depicts a vicious beastâ€¦

Ask the PCs the following questions:

  • What is the name of the beast?

  • What does it look like?

  • Why is it so dangerous?

After Building the Monsterâ€™s Description & Lore

Written below the sun-bleached images and descriptions of the monster are tales of travelers mysteriously disappearing with little trace. The only known person to escape the monster was a Halfling named Gruff. Lastly, a note at the bottom directs you to seek out Eugene at the Bloodsworn Guild Hall to accept the contract.

Arriving at Bloodsworn Guild Hall

You head to the nearby Guild Hall, red banners depicting the symbol of the Bloodsworn wave in the wind. The sounds of arrows and swords striking training dummies fills your ears as you step into a wide dirt-covered chamber. Youâ€™re pointed in the direction of the Warden of the Bloodsworn, a grizzled man with a wrinkled face and gray slicked-back hair sitting with his feet up on a thick wooden desk. He introduces himself as Eugene, sits up, and extends a hand expectantlyâ€¦

In a raspy but firm voice he says, â€œLet me see the bounty youâ€™ve chosen. Assuming youâ€™re not here as tourists, that is.â€

Eugene makes the following comments:

  • â€œGoing after this ferocious creature, eh? Havenâ€™t seen anyone go after this beast in a while. Havenâ€™t seen anyone come back neitherâ€¦â€

  • â€œWhatâ€™s your group called? I need to know what to put on the gravestones should you not returnâ€¦â€

  • â€œIf everything goes to hell, who can I hold responsible for any of your blunders?â€

  • â€œItâ€™s a good thing thereâ€™s [number of PCs] of yaâ€¦ we Bloodsworn find that to be the perfect size for our missions.â€

  • â€œBefore I give you the contract, show me what ya got. I want to see what keeps ya alive when your backâ€™s against the wall.â€ (Proceed to Scene 3 after this line

The Party now has to prove themselves in a Social Challenge. The better they do, the more rewards they get.

Social Challenge

  • Challenge DC: 12

  • Success Points: # of PCs

Challenge Rules

Explaining Challenges To Your Players:

Challenges are a fun way to resolve dramatic moments. You will each describe what your character is attempting to do to impress the Warden of the Bloodsworn and Iâ€™ll determine what Check that corresponds to. Youâ€™ll then make a Check against the Challenge DC. The better you do as a group, the more rewards youâ€™ll get!

PCs are trying to earn a certain number of Success Points. Checks can be made in order or all at once (depending on the GMâ€™s preference or the playersâ€™ descriptions). Duplicate Checks are made at DisADV (unless the description is amazing.

  • Success (each 5): The party gains 1 Success Point (+1 more point for a Critical Success).

  • Failure: The party gains no Success Points.

  • Critical Failure: The party loses 1 Success Point (You can ignore the Critical Failure rule if you want to be nicer to your Players)

Free Spellcasting

Spells cost 0 MP during Challenges, but add to the flavor of the Check.

Failing Forward

No matter what the end result of the Challenge, the PCs are assumed to have performed well enough to get the contract. The extent to which they impress Eugene is determined by the number of Success Points they earn (see Resolution).

Resolution

When the Challenge is over, the party receives the following based on the number of Success Points theyâ€™ve earned.

  • Success: A number of @UUID[Item.EESEyNqYufY0ZdiF]{Healing Potion} equal to the number of PCs.

  • Each Extra Success: An @UUID[Item.6tQD3QEFwnPuF6Of]{Invisibility Potion}, @UUID[Item.RoLOlWL410MyBrgL]{Silence Trap}, or additional @UUID[Item.EESEyNqYufY0ZdiF]{Healing Potion}.

  • Failure: A number of @UUID[Item.EESEyNqYufY0ZdiF]{Healing Potion} equal to half the number of PCs.

After the Challenge

Once the PCs finish the Social Challenge and officially get their contract, Eugene gives them a warning.

Eugene hands you a map with a circled area and says, â€œOk now so for this areaâ€¦ letâ€™s seeâ€¦ yup, you gotta watch out for them there krasis and wobblety-gobblers as you make your way there. Theyâ€™ve been spotted along that path. Try not to make too much noise, ya hear? Both of them creatures use echolocation to see real good. QUITE dangerous, they are. Will for sure kill ya. But you should be fine with just the [Monsterâ€™s Name]. Good luck now!

After turning around to leave the training facility with their contract, the rival adventuring party stops the PCs. They had their eyes on the same contract the party just earned and theyâ€™re not pleased to have it â€œstolenâ€ from them.

DC Tip: Try and weave in some custom dialogue based onwhat the PCs said about HOW they became rivals. They willeventually be fighting this group, so it helps to plant the seedsof their rivalry now.

Leaving the Guild Hall

As you step back out into the sunlight, a large mountain of a man steps in front of you all. You hear a snarky and slightly squeaky voice from behind the figure say

  • â€œHey there! Now that right there is OUR contract!â€

This line is echoed by a much deeper, slower voice from the creature before you,

  • â€œYEAH, OUR CONTRACT!â€

These two creatures are Buff and Gruff, members of The Shadows

Meeting Buff & Gruff

The giant pile of muscle in front of you is a large Giantborn named Buff. His skin is as thick as a dinosaurâ€™s and his brainâ€™s as big as a dinosaurâ€™s too. Crawling out from behind his back and onto his shoulder is his older brother Gruff, a small Halfling man with a flowing shirt thatâ€™s left open down to his belly button.

The party is welcome to engage with these 2 in whatever manner they choose. Buff and Gruff will likely taunt the players with the following banter, often with Buff echoing Gruff like before:

  • â€œThereâ€™s no way you can take out the [Monsterâ€™s Name].â€

  • â€œWhatever man/lady, youâ€™re all gonna die.â€

  • â€œTwo different parties sent out by the Bloodsworn for that creature came back in pieces.â€

When this conversation draws towards an end, Gruff tries to get the contract from them.

Gruff's Offer

  • â€œWeâ€™re here to do you a favor, okay. You seem like nice folk, so why not just pass us the contract and go on with your lives. Thereâ€™s no reason for you guys to die trying to be heroes. Giveit toâ€¦â€

Before Gruff can finish his sentence, heâ€™s interrupted. You see a veiled woman in black, assassin style leathers step out from the shadows with a large black crossbowon her back and short black hair swept across half of her face. Her speech is calm and soft-spoken, though chillingly authoritarian, as she says,

â€œLet them goâ€¦itâ€™sâ€¦whatever. Their time will come soon enough. Come on, weâ€™re leavingâ€¦â€

The Shadows depart and leave the party to find their way toward the adventure site.

Leaving the CIty LimIts

You leave the city on the back of a Bloodsworn caravan, set to take you to your destination. The autumn skies and bright yellow sun create an orange glow on the horizon as you travel down a well-traveled dirt road. The trip takes a few hours before you hear a grumbly voice.

  • â€œAlright, [Group Name] this is your spotâ€.

Youâ€™re free to describe the scenery however you want, in a way that fits the partyâ€™s target as described by you and the players earlier. However, here is the suggested location for the next 2 Scenes.

Continuing On Foot

Squat trees decorate most of this swampy environment, sending dangling vines and droopy branches to impede your travels. The muddy trail ahead of you is swallowed by water at random intervals, the murk keeping you from being able to tell how deep the puddles and ponds truly are. Tall grass grows in the few areas that arenâ€™t blocked from direct sunlight.

The party can be dropped off miles from the next Sceneâ€™s location or mere minutes away. The length of this Scene is left up to the GMâ€™s discretion. It can be as detailed as a Challenge of your own making or as simple as a couple scene-setting comments.

Map: @UUID[Scene.yi8qKGIjobjuIO5v]{Scene 7: Swamp}

Monsters: @UUID[Actor.zPt9s0hUx0ReAJyc]{Raven}, @UUID[Actor.QNQV1ZVnXafFNyVa]{Buff}, @UUID[Actor.cEJYrnrTLGeu2hbU]{Gruff}, @UUID[Actor.U2w7BG3cgXxZvVct]{Haze}, @UUID[Actor.FosnvN5sLJXnGBzG]{Nightmare}, @UUID[Actor.A0NS7TBE7TsCAegA]{Shadow}

Once the party finishes the Challenge above, they are ambushed by the Shadows. The rivals have come to take a trophy of the target and credit for the kill.

The Shadows Arrive

As you finish your struggle with the [Monsterâ€™s Name], you hear sarcastic clapping coming from behind you as The Shadows show themselves. Raven, the young elf from before, leads them forwardâ€¦

  • Gruff: â€œWe told ya to stay away, now ya gotta pay.â€

  • Buff: â€œYEAH, YA GOTTA PAY!â€

  • Raven: â€œWeâ€™ve been watching your group for quite some time, and nowâ€¦now you all disappear. Weâ€™ll kill you just like we did the last group and their bounders. Any last words, amateursâ€¦?â€

  • Buff: â€œYEAH, AMATEURS!â€

  • Raven: â€œShut up, Buff!â€

Rival Combat

  • Encounter DC: 14

  • Initiative DC: 19

  • Number of Rivals: Equal to # of PCs

Running The Combat

Upon establishing the Initiative Order, set up the battlefield using your best judgment to determine where the enemies are placed in relation to the PCs. Depending on the setting youâ€™ve described to the players thus far, consider adding obstacles and points of cover to the landscape. Areas of difficult terrain such as bramble bushes, thick mud patches, or a path of uneven rocks are great ways to shape the battlefield.

Start of Round 1

Raven, Gruff, and Buff are the only Rivals that will always be part of this fight. 1 additional rival is added to this combat until the number of enemies equals the number of PCs.

Surprise Rival

Because Bloodsworn parties are always made up of a certain group size, you can hide one of them in the nearby trees or swamp pools. If thereâ€™s more than 3 Rivals, one of the casters Spell Dueling a PC during the first round of Combat is a great reveal, especially if the party notices theyâ€™re missing one or more members and try to search for them.

Resolution

The rivals have the following notable items on their person, in addition to any obvious weapons or armor the party wishes to take.

  • 1 @UUID[Item.Qiw6w4VPkNB5m2SY]{Green Poison Vial} (2 Poison damage if consumed)

  • 1 @UUID[Item.EESEyNqYufY0ZdiF]{Healing Potion} per Rival defeated.

After confronting their contract target and surviving the ambush from The Shadows, the party will likely need to take some time to rest and recover before heading back through the wilderness to town.

Taking a Rest

Having survived a series of encounters, you have the chance to settle down for a Quick or Short Rest. Quick Rests take 10 minutes, while Short Rests take 1 hour. You can be mildly active during either rest, but canâ€™t do anything strenuous. You remember that you need to get back to the pick up location before dark, which Rest would you prefer to take as the sun starts to dip in the sky?

Both Rests allow PCs to expend Rest Points to regain HP, but a Short Rest might allow the party to regain some other resources.

Rest Points - A PC regains 2 HP per Rest Point they spend.

Roleplay During Rests

Itâ€™s heavily encouraged that players use Rests as a time to break out of the tension built during an adventure and foster connections and unique story moments between their PCs. This could be simple campfire stories, a probing question asked by one PC to another, or a chance to share personal details about oneâ€™s PC with the party.

Leading Questions from the GM

Consider prompting your players with these questions, or ones of your own:

  • How does [PCâ€™s Name] feel about current progress being made?

  • What is the most pressing thing on [PCâ€™s Name]â€™s mind at this moment?

  • What from the last few Scenes had the biggest impact on [PCâ€™s Name]?

  • For which of the PCs would [PCâ€™s Name] have a question?

  • About which piece of new information is [PCâ€™s Name] thinking?

  • When you get back to Eugene, what are you planning on telling him?

  • [PCâ€™s Name], do recent events remind you of anything from your past?

  • What were your thoughts when you first encountered or killed the bounty?

  • After fighting your rivals, what rumors have you confirmed were true about them?

Map: @UUID[Scene.uaDbdOBRClhO3dRl]{Scene 9: Conflict}

Monsters: @UUID[Actor.hbYPmXFG6Z4mNLA9]{Krasis}, @UUID[Actor.6SOEvNiBnRDfbUwC]{Young Krasis}

The PCs are ambushed by a wild monster, a krasis, as they make their way back through its territory on the way to the Bloodsworn caravan. If your PCs are being particularly careful as they make their way back, and remember the warning that Eugene gave them at the start, you could give them a means of avoiding the Krasis ambushing them.

Avoiding The Ambush: If a PC mentions being careful or alert on the way back to the Bloodsworn caravan, have them make a DC 15 Awareness Check.
Success: Continue reading. Players will still make Fate Rolls to see who the Krasis jumps towards, but that PC isnâ€™t knocked Prone.

Nearing The Clearing Outside Wildfang:

While making your way back through the wild forests outside Wildfang, you begin to hear a low-pitched but loud gurgling. As you pause and begin to investigate, I need you all to make a Fate Roll.

Fate Rolls

Each player rolls 1d20. The Krasis leaps out from hiding and jumps on the PC with the lowest Fate Roll.

  • Natural 20: Any player that rolls a 20 on their Fate Roll prevents the ambush from the Krasis. Allow them to describe how they avoid the ambush or save the ally that was about to get jumped on.

After Fate Rolls (remember lowest result):

A large shape leaps out of the nearby pond and crashes down upon [PC with lowest Fate Roll], knocking you prone.

This creature is an enormous reptilian beast standing 10 feet tall even while hunched over. A massive tail, powerful hindlegs, and long thin limbs make up the bulk of its form while a crocodile-like snout extends past a large leathery pouch. Its throat swells as it lets out a strong, bellowing roar, which seems to call upon a few younglings that swarm in around you. This is a Krasis, one of the creatures Eugene warned about, and youâ€™ve seemed to stumble upon its brood.

The Krasis let the party leave when they first made their way through this area towards their contract, but a second transgression through its territory will not go unpunished.

Krasis Combat

  • Encounter DC: 14

  • Initiative DC: 19

Running The Combat

Reference the @UUID[Scene.uaDbdOBRClhO3dRl]{Map}. The PCs start in the bottom left of the map, making their way up and to the right. The Krasis ambushes them just before the treeline bottlenecks towards the middle of the map.

Minions

@UUID[Actor.hbYPmXFG6Z4mNLA9]{The Krasis} starts this encounter with a number of @UUID[Actor.6SOEvNiBnRDfbUwC]{Young Krasis} equal to the number of PCs minus 1.

Resolution

Returning To The Guild Hall:

Upon returning to the Bloodsworn Guild Hall, Eugene appears pleasantly surprised with your actions. Hearing the trouble involving Raven and her goons brings concerns of other fractures within the guild. Perhaps he will require your assistance in the future. As for now, youâ€™re rewarded with the following:

  • Initiate Badge of the Bloodsworn.

  • Access to the Guild Hall, except for the war room.

  • A voucher for 1 free meal.

This adventure is designed to be setting agnostic and is presented in a way to ease those dropping this introductory story into any world.

Party Level: This adventure is written for 1st-level PCs, though it can be tailored to fit slightly higher-level characters with a few tweaks.

Party Goal: Gaining the reputation necessary to earn the title of Reaper might become a goal of the party. More dangerous monsters can earn the party more pay and more renown, allowing them to rise through the ranks.

The city of Wildfang is located in the center of the realm and is populated by warriors, hunters, and sages known as The Bloodsworn. These brave souls protect the surrounding kingdoms by slaying all manner of dangerous beasts that roam the neighboring kingdoms. The Bloodsworn are a guild of monster hunters contracted by the local lords to protect and defend their lands. The most elite of them gain the title of Reaper. You are a lowly adventuring party, and will need to work your way up through the ranks, one contract at a time, if you seek to join the ranks of these master hunters.

After reading the Adventure Summary go through as ask the Players each of these questions:

  • What are your Character names?

  • Who is the leader of the group?

  • What is your group's name?

  • You all have upset a rival adventuring party. What did you all do to become rivals with them?

What the PCsâ€™ Know: The Rival Adventuring party is known as â€œThe Shadowsâ€ and their leader goes by â€œRavenâ€. This gothic group doesnâ€™t play by the rules, cutting corners and skirting the edge of the law while fulfilling their contracts. They get results, but their methods are a bit rough around the edges

Rivals: The Shadows

The Rival Adventuring party has the exact same number of members as there are Player Characters (minimum of 3 rivals). The group always has Raven (leader) as well as Gruff & Buff (half-Halfling Giantborns).

You can add on as many secondary members as you need to have their party size match the PCsâ€™ numbers. Keep the other members ofthe group a secret or have them act as lesser NPCs doing work in the background.

  • @UUID[Actor.zPt9s0hUx0ReAJyc]{Raven} Female Elf

    • Cool, soft-spoken authoritarian

    • Leader

    • Crossbow Rogue

  • @UUID[Actor.cEJYrnrTLGeu2hbU]{Gruff} Male Halfling

    • Short-tempered, excitable

    • Second-in-command

    • Meteor Hammer Monk

  • @UUID[Actor.QNQV1ZVnXafFNyVa]{Buff} Male Giantborn

    • Big, dumb brute

    • Bruiser

    • Grapple Barbarian

  • @UUID[Actor.U2w7BG3cgXxZvVct]{Haze}

    • Standoffish lonewolf

    • The tracker

    • Longbow Ranger

  • @UUID[Actor.A0NS7TBE7TsCAegA]{Shadow} Male Dwarf

    • Dark, sinister, crazed

    • Healer

    • Umbral Cleric

  • @UUID[Actor.FosnvN5sLJXnGBzG]{Nightmare}

    • Overly confident and studious

    • Support and crowd control

    • Illusionist Wizard

Once the PCs find their way along the trail to the creature theyâ€™re hunting, they come upon the ruins of a fortress thatâ€™s sinking into the terrain of these lands. This is where they encounter their target and engage in a Combat Challenge.

Approaching Monsterâ€™s Location:

Following the signs of your prey, youâ€™re led to a ruined castle buried within the terrain. The grounds before you are littered with the bloodied corpses of a pack of bounders. These kangaroo-like beasts are used by The Bloodsworn as transportation. The blood is still wet, leaving you to suspect that these kills were recent.

The target creature is what killed the bounders, and itâ€™s lurking nearbyâ€¦

Combat Challenge

  • Challenge DC: 12

  • Success Points: # of PCs

DC Tip: Since this is your second Challenge within this adventure. You should feel more comfortable adjusting these two numbers above to make the Challenge easier or harder for your players.

A higher DC makes each roll more difficult and dramatic, but more Success Points needed is generally the better number to adjust since it allows players to succeed, but still decreases the success rate.

Challenge Rules

PCs are attempting to slay the creature depicted in their contract. Each player makes 1 Check to earn Success Points for their party.

  • Success (each 5): The party gains 1 Success Point (+1 more point for a Critical Success).

  • Failure (each 5): The PC who failed takes 1 True damage (+1 more damage on a Critical Failure).

Failing Forward

No matter what the end result of the Challenge, the PCs are assumed to have performed well enough to complete the contract. The amount of damage the monster deals to each PC during this Challenge is determined by the number of Success Points they earn (see Resolution).

DC Tip: Again, this shows that Challenges are NOT designed to stop the progression of the story, but to add risks and mechanical guidance to these cinematic and fun moments.

Challenge Guidance

Below is a list of example tactics and actions the PC might attempt to defeat their contract target. After each Check is made, describe the level of success it has as if you were running a combat.

  • Attack Check: Attack it.

  • Spell Check: Cast a spell.

  • Awareness: Locate it or track its movements.

  • Stealth: Sneak up on it or land a hidden strike.

  • Athletics: Restrain or overpower it.

  • Trickery: Confuse or distract it.

  • Survival: Trap it or detect its attack patterns.

  • Animal: Calm it or guide your allies in battle against it.

DC Tip: Itâ€™s ideal to end your descriptions during Challenges with new leading details that the next player can grab and run with. An Attack doesnâ€™t just hit when your player succeeds on their Check, it instead sends the creature flying into the crumbling castle, causing large chunks of rock to break off from the walls and land around the battlefield. Resolution

When the Challenge is over, the result is calculated based on the number of Success Points theyâ€™ve earned.

  • Success: The PCs take no additional damage.

  • Failure: Each PC who failed their Check takes 1 additional True damage.

DC Tip: The difference in this Challengeâ€™s resolution showcases that sometimes Challenges are just to avoid bad things happening (this Challenge), rather than to see how many rewards the party receives (Eugeneâ€™s Challenge). The best reward here is taking ZERO damage during the Challenge.
